docs.snippet: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). “What we got here is failure to communicate,” says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman), a war hero, has been sentenced for two years after cutting th...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). “What we got here is failure to communicate,” says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman), a war hero, has been sentenced for two years after cutting the heads off parking meters. Mr. Newman earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as a prisoner who refuses to break under a brutal system. George Kennedy won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Dragline, the gang’s top dog. At 10:30, Steve McQueen and Dustin Hoffman play convicts trying to escape Devil’s Island in “Papillon” (1973).

docs.snippet: Quite a few categories in this year’s Oscar race bring all of the challenge of the wading pool.  While some head out to the deep end....

headline.main: Some Hints, Before You Dive Into the Oscar Pool

docs.snippet: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). ''What we got here is failure to communicate,'' says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman, front, with Wayne Rogers, far left, and J. D. Cannon), a war her...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (AMC) COOL HAND LUKE (1967). ''What we got here is failure to communicate,'' says Captain (Strother Martin), the warden in charge of the chain gang to which Luke (Paul Newman, front, with Wayne Rogers, far left, and J. D. Cannon), a war hero, has been sentenced for two years after cutting the heads off parking meters. Mr. Newman earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as a prisoner who refuses to break under a brutal system. George Kennedy won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as Dragline, the gang's top dog. At 10:30, Steve McQueen and Dustin Hoffman play convicts trying to escape Devil's Island in ''Papillon'' (1973). 8 P.M. (CMT) COWBOY U -- With boot camp finished, the city slickers must put their newfound skills to the test on a two-day cattle drive, followed by a calf-branding session. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER -- Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) goes after a corpse (Jamie Bamber of ''Battlestar Galactica,'' in a guest turn, right, with Ms. Hewitt) from a local morgue who was reanimated by a spirit that needs this particular body to get his work done. 9 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Forensics? Who needs it? Monk uses his detective skills to find a serial killer in San Francisco when he is teamed with a technologically astute federal agent. 9 P.M. (Sundance) LADETTE TO LADY -- The six remaining ladettes compete for three positions as chalet girls in Verbier, the Swiss ski resort. But it's not just about breezing down the bunny slope, as the winners are put to work creating gourmet meals for eight hungry but eligible bachelors. The losers have to learn elocution and flower arranging. 10 P.M. (TLC) THE GREATEST FASHION ICONS IN FILM -- Just in time for red-carpet analysis at the Oscars, a special that looks at the ones who clearly did know what to wear. And where would any list of the sartorially savvy be without a mention of Audrey Hepburn, her little black dress and her little slim pants, now interpreted for a new generation by the Gap? There's also a nod to contemporary stars and their fashion influences. 10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER -- The smoking glove? A publisher is found dead after backing out of a deal regarding a controversial book in which a baseball player speculates how he might have murdered his wife. 11 P.M. (BBC America) SPOONS -- This new sketch comedy series about the fragile relationships (bad sex, worse marriages) of young urbanites deals in types, including the paranoid boyfriend, the clueless husband and the wife who can't have a baby soon enough. The comic stable includes (above) Tom Goodman-Hill, Rosie Cavaliero, Simon Farnaby, Rob Rouse, Elizabeth Bower, Kerry Godliman, Josie D'Arby and Kevin Bishop. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

docs.snippet: When the Bagger mingles with the stars, magic happens. Sort of....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger has spent the season in variety of poses: free-loader, Oscar savant, handmaiden to the stars, but for the most part, he has been in his basement mostly typing, lots and lots of typing. But every now and then he got out to "mingle" with the stars. Here is a selection of those red-carpet moments.
docs.abstract: When the Bagger mingles with the stars, magic happens. Sort of.

docs.snippet: The Bagger, the only Oscar Ninny at fancy L.A. party....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger spent quite a bit of time winding his way through the hills of Los Angeles last night, looking for a party for Matthew Hiltzik, a guy with a Ph.D. in the theromodynamics of spin and the head of the American arm of Freud Communications, an international public relations company. Mr. Hiltzik used to work for Harvey Weinstein and has a lot of pals in the business, including Jason Blum, a producer, who offered the use of his amazing home in the hills.
docs.abstract: The Bagger, the only Oscar Ninny at fancy L.A. party.

docs.snippet: A chart that tells you what everybody knows: nothing....
docs.lead_paragraph: Later today, the Bagger will lock up his Oscar picks and post them for your viewing pleasure tomorrow. But for the time being, you can see where almost everyone is landing over at OscarWatch. It's a beautifully done color chart, but instead of clarifying the race, it demonstrates that this year people are going to be all over the road right up until the last minute.
docs.abstract: A chart that tells you what everybody knows: nothing.

docs.snippet: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL In her first Oscar salute, Ms. Winfrey asked three Academy Award-winning actors to interview the Oscar winner they’d most like to hear from. The pairings: Julia Roberts meets George Clooney at his Lo...
docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL In her first Oscar salute, Ms. Winfrey asked three Academy Award-winning actors to interview the Oscar winner they’d most like to hear from. The pairings: Julia Roberts meets George Clooney at his Los Angeles home; Nicole Kidman takes on Russell Crowe in the Beverly Hills Hotel; and Jamie Foxx interviews Sidney Poitier on the stage where he won his Oscar for “Lilies of the Field” in 1963.

docs.snippet: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL -- In her first Oscar salute, Ms. Winfrey asked three Academy Award-winning actors to interview the Oscar winner they'd most like to hear from. The pairings: Julia Roberts meets George Clooney (above) ...
docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE OPRAH WINFREY OSCAR SPECIAL -- In her first Oscar salute, Ms. Winfrey asked three Academy Award-winning actors to interview the Oscar winner they'd most like to hear from. The pairings: Julia Roberts meets George Clooney (above) at his Los Angeles home; Nicole Kidman takes on Russell Crowe in the Beverly Hills Hotel; and Jamie Foxx interviews Sidney Poitier on the stage where he won his Oscar for ''Lilies of the Field'' in 1963. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL -- Two men and two women are sent packing.9 P.M. (Fox) THE O.C. Subtitle this one ''The End's Not Near, It's Here.'' Tonight, in this series finale, the pretty people of Orange County bid adieu six months after an earthquake rocked Newport, and viewers find out what ever happened to the Cohens, the Coopers, and the rest. 8 P.M. (VH1) BLING'D: BLOOD, DIAMONDS AND HIP-HOP -- Last summer, the hip-hop artists Paul Wall, Raekwon of Wu Tang Clan, and Tego Calderon traveled to Sierra Leone to look at the diamond trade, which has devastated communities, forced women, children (above, with Mr. Wall in Kono) and the elderly into being miners and helped finance the country's civil war. Back in the United States, Kanye West, Jadakiss, Big Daddy Kane, Juelz Santana, Chris Aire and Mr. T come to terms with what it means to wear bling in the American hip-hop world. Says Mr. West, ''It's just ironic that what made black people feel so empowered was completely demoralizing and destroying other black people.'' 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY'S ANATOMY -- Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) fights for her life. 9 P.M. (Biography) CRUCIBLES OF COURAGE -- Barack Obama, the Illinois senator and Democratic presidential candidate, is host of this hour long special, which honors five African-Americans who have changed society. The heavyweights on the list are Thurgood Marshall, the Supreme Court justice; the Olympian Jesse Owens; the politician Shirley Chisholm; the contralto Marian Anderson; and Muhammad Ali. 9:30 P.M. (HBO) GHOSTS OF ABU GHRAIB -- To see the pictures was to ask some uncomfortable questions -- like how did torture become an accepted practice at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq? Did the policies of the United States government make it possible? And how much damage has been done to America's credibility? In this film, an official selection in the American Documentary Competition at the 2007 Sundance Film Festival, Rory Kennedy interviews Iraqi victims (above) and guards directly involved in the abuses. KATHRYN SHATTUCK
